name: Curcumin
summary: Curcumin is the primary bioactive compound in turmeric (Curcuma longa) with anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and potential antidepressant and neuroprotective effects.
description: Curcumin is a polyphenolic compound derived from turmeric, a spice long used in traditional Ayurvedic and Chinese medicine. It exerts broad biological effects including inhibition of inflammatory pathways, modulation of neurotransmitters, enhancement of neurogenesis, and protection against oxidative stress. Curcumin is being studied for its role in mood disorders, cognitive decline, and neurodegenerative diseases, though its clinical impact is limited by poor bioavailability unless formulated with absorption enhancers (e.g., piperine).

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved as a drug)

monitoring_required: Liver function if used long-term in high doses

items: Adjunctive treatment in major depressive disorder
Cognitive decline and Alzheimer’s disease prevention (investigational)

sections.text: Curcumin exerts its effects by modulating inflammatory signaling pathways (e.g., NF-κB), reducing oxidative stress, regulating neurotransmitter levels (serotonin, dopamine), and promoting neuroplasticity through BDNF upregulation. These properties may underlie its antidepressant and neuroprotective effects.

adult.typical: 500–2,000 mg/day of standardized curcumin extract (often divided doses), usually combined with piperine or formulated for enhanced absorption
adult.note: Dosage varies depending on formulation; bioavailability-enhanced preparations are preferred.

sections.text: Mood effects may be observed within 4–8 weeks of supplementation; anti-inflammatory benefits can appear sooner.

other: Avoid high doses in individuals with bleeding disorders or those on anticoagulants.

items: Bleeding symptoms if combined with anticoagulants
Liver function in high-dose long-term use

sections.pregnancy: Likely safe in dietary amounts; avoid high-dose supplements
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid unless directed by clinician
sections.geriatrics: Potentially beneficial for inflammation and cognition

sections.text: No taper required; can be discontinued without withdrawal effects.

items: Curcumin has very low natural bioavailability; formulations with piperine, phospholipids, or nanoparticles are recommended.
May serve as an adjunctive therapy in depression with mild-to-moderate benefit.
Research into neurodegenerative disease prevention is ongoing but inconclusive.
